This statement can be dramatically simplified. You should almost never provide `nil` as [a default value][1] or use `nil?` in a conditional like this.

```ruby
Albacore.log_level = Logger::DEBUG if ENV["DEBUG"]
```

 [1]: http://www.ruby-doc.org/core-2.0/ENV.html#method-c-fetch

There's some [ruby style guide warnings][1] about using these `STD*` constants. Not sure if it applies here, but good reading.

 [1]: https://github.com/bbatsov/ruby-style-guide

In Ruby, only `nil` and `false` evaluate to `false`. You can rewrite these statements to say "raise an argument error unless the argument has a value"

```ruby
raise ArgumentError, "blah blah blah" unless output
```
When I'm not operating on the `*args`, I've taken to just sending them down to the Rake library. Let them pass/fail down there.

false by default because it's not defined - @AnthonyMastrean - what do you think of this coding pattern? I think we could at least have a `attr_accessor :keep_to`, remove the method, add rdoc on top of the `attr_accessor` and default it to false (instead of undefined)

I thought @AnthonyMastrean wanted to avoid setting Boolean flags. We can initialize it to false by default to make it more explicit in implementation.

You don't need to test the `command` value. It's `nil` by default, can only be a value or `nil`, and `@command` is `nil` by default. So there's no harm in always setting it, right?

    @command = command

You don't need to test the `command` value. It's `nil` by default, can only be a value or `nil`, and `@command` is `nil` by default. So there's no harm in always setting it, right?

    @command = command

`nil` and `false` are the only values that resolve to `false` in Ruby. So you can write a more concise postfix statement like this

    params << " /tag=#{@tag}" if @tag

The existing codebase uses the more verbose/confusing syntax, but we're trying to change it one bit at a time :) It would be ok to change all of the `unless` statements in this block.

I'm sorry, I wasn't clear. You should write the statement like

`unless <nil?>` is equivalent to `if <value>`

When creating a new gemspec/gemfile skeleton with Bundler (my preferred way of creating those files), it drops these two lines in your gemspec

```ruby
lib = File.expand_path('../lib', __FILE__)
$LOAD_PATH.unshift(lib) unless $LOAD_PATH.include?(lib)
```

Maybe I'll just update our gemspec to match the Bundler created gemspec. They must be good conventions, right?

Rubygems doesn't support the actual [semver spec][1] for prerelease versions, that is, with the hyphen `1.0.0-rc.1`. It will accept a dotted version, `1.0.0.rc.1`. Which reads a little odd to me, but [should work inside Rubygems][2].

 [1]: http://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html
 [2]: http://guides.rubygems.org/patterns/#prerelease_gems

Thanks! I'm going to look it over with @haf, I had a [similar pull request](https://github.com/derickbailey/Albacore/pull/200) on Derick's repo that took a hash of _any_ other switches. Obviously, the most used switches/properties should be first-class, but some, like `fileloggerparameters` get no love!

It looks good, so does yours Anthony -- but I think we can make the ruby a bit nicer for all of these switches, by doing a Hash.merge and then if we use Array.collect rather than a loop.

I'm not at all against merging this directly though.

I also think our next focus should be making MSBuild work transparently with both xbuild and MSBuild so that we can enable the unit tests on travis for that task. What do you think?

Let's merge this just to get it in! What's our release cadence? We could merge all the way to master and release a patch version (0.3.1)? Or release every passing dev branch commit as a pre-release (let's have a conversation on the google group or over email)?

I'll play with my pull request next week or so and see how it works together. You can show me how/where you'd use hash merge and array collect.

I think that your "milestone" of making msbuild work transparently is great for the community _and_ the build.
Sure, go ahead :)

To answer your question I used `'subdir/.'` because I want to test that this code 
```ruby
@o.to "#{OutputTestData.to}/subdir/"
````
creates a directory not relies on directory created by dir method. `'/.'` is used to reference contents of the folder not the folder itself. 
Example ( copying lib folder from albacore gem )
```shell
➜  mkdir bla
➜  cp -r lib bla
➜  ls bla
lib
➜  rm -rf bla
➜  cp -r lib/. bla
➜  ls bla
albacore    albacore.rb version.rb
```

I'm not a fan of the boolean property setter like this. It [can be confusing][3] to interpret what kind of value to assign, boolean (`false`) or symbol (`:false`), or if it's a method call. I like the method syntax. For example,
* xunit task, [`skip_test_failures`][1]
* msbuild task, [`nologo`][2]

The name `remove_dir_to` isn't as friendly as it could be. It's not totally consistent with the `from` and `to` properties. It's true by default, internally. So, should this property only be set when intended to be false?

What about a method for just the file-preserving behavior, named very specifically? I could support

* `keep_to`
* `preserve_to`
* `dont_clean`
* `no_overwrite`
* `no_clean`

I feel like there's a better name I haven't thought of yet, thoughts?

----
FYI, it feels like it would be easier to name if we switched the default behavior to _never_ clean and had a method _to clean_... then we could just say `out.clean`. But, that's not in the cards.


 [1]: https://github.com/Albacore/albacore/blob/dev/lib/albacore/xunittestrunner.rb#L18
 [2]: https://github.com/Albacore/albacore/blob/dev/lib/albacore/msbuild.rb#L22
 [3]: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8701295
Ah right didn't get this albacore convention. I have changed it to `keep_to` sounds like the most appropriate to me.

This looks great. But, we prefer to use methods that indicate the non-default behavior (see Issue #21 for another example). In this case, simply calling `force` 

    unzip do |unzip|
      unzip.destination = File.dirname(__FILE__)
      unzip.file = "Archive.zip"
      unzip.force
    end

should set the internal state `@force = true`.

    attr_reader :force

    def force
      @force = true
    end

Does that seem reasonable?

I appreciate the discovery and the fix! But, the extra assignment is unnecessary. Especially if you leave the post-fix guard clause in. I always think of postfix operators as "do this or nothing at all". So, I would try one of the two styles of ternary statements.

This fake way depends on a statement always returning it's last value. So, if `@flatten_zip` is `false`, the statement is `nil`.

    file_path = (file_path.split('/').last if @flatten_zip) || file_path

Or, use the actual ternary operator

    file_path = @flatten_zip ? file_path.split('/').last : file_path

What do you think?

Ah yes that makes sense, I just copied the method for zip_directory, but I agree and I probably prefer the || operator.

```ruby
  def zip_directory(zipfile)
    return if @directories_to_zip.nil?
    @directories_to_zip.each do |d|
      Dir["#{d}/**/**"].reject{|f| reject_file(f)}.each do |file_path|
        file_name = file_path
        file_name = file_path.sub(d + '/','') if @flatten_zip
        zipfile.add(file_name, file_path)
      end
    end
  end
```

Do you want me to change that and resubmit a pull? (this was my first pull request and actually my first contribution to any project!)

I've added a test for the flatten_zip behaviour and changed the code to use the ternary as I didn't like the extra braces needed for the ||.

One curious thing: when I was writing the test, if I used the existing ZipTestData for the folder to zip (which uses File.expand) then I would get the following message:


    1) ZipDirectory with flatten_zip set to false should add additional file
     Failure/Error: zip.execute
     Zip::ZipEntryNameError:
       Illegal ZipEntry name '/home/jallen/dev/projects/albacore/spec/support/zip/files', name must not start with /

Which is why I had to specify the folders.

    1) ZipDirectory with flatten_zip set to false should add additional file
     Failure/Error: zip.execute
     Zip::ZipEntryNameError:
       Illegal ZipEntry name '/home/jallen/dev/projects/albacore/spec/support/zip/files', name must not start with /

Which is why I had to specify the folders.

Oh, I see that Ruby 2.0 has a 64-bit installer. That's new to me! You can run Ruby from a directory (pick up the 32-bit "portable" install), install gems to that "local" Ruby, and execute rspec from it instead of your globally available Ruby.

@haf Are we going back to being in charge of all possible install paths? I stripped all path searching out of 1.0 because it was getting crazy.

I think the msbuild is a such a frequently used path that it should be searched for actually...

For all the other tools, no, I don't think we should hard-code them. But in fact, I as a the author of most of the code in this repo for this version, don't know the path of msbuild on the top of my head.

If the user doesn't find msbuild through the 'hard-coded' paths, then they might as well set the msbuild binary on the user/system path like is the custom when using console applications, so I'm not *that* concerned about changes to this particular code.

Released v2.3.15

Here's what you specify in your gemfile to fetch directly from this repository:

``` bash
gem 'albacore', :git => 'https://github.com/Albacore/albacore.git'
```


http://bundler.io/git.html
